items.title: United States: Bill to end government shutdown passes the Senate, heads to House
items.standfirst: The longest US government shutdown moved closer to ending on Monday (November 10) after several Democrats joined Republicans in a 60-40 vote for a compromise funding deal, drawing party backlash.
items.content: The longest US government shutdown moved closer to ending on Monday (November 10) after several Democrats joined Republicans in a 60-40 vote for a compromise funding deal, drawing party backlash.

items.title: How Governors Became Voice for Voiceless Democratic Party

items.title: Shutdown Nears End as Senate Passes Funding Bill
US Senate passes bill to end government shutdown, sending it to House
items.standfirst: The longest US government shutdown moved closer to ending on Monday (November 10) after several Democrats joined Republicans in a 60-40 vote for a compromise funding deal, drawing party backlash. The shutdown, now in its 40th day, has left over a million workers unpaid and caused major air travel disruptions.
items.content: The longest US government shutdown moved closer to ending on Monday (November 10) after several Democrats joined Republicans in a 60-40 vote for a compromise funding deal, drawing party backlash. The shutdown, now in its 40th day, has left over a million workers unpaid and caused major air travel disruptions.

items.title: Senate approves package to end government shutdown, sending to House
items.standfirst: The Senate approved a long-sought funding package that would end the government shutdown late Monday, bringing Congress one step closer to ending a 41-day impasse.
items.content: The Senate approved a long-sought funding package that would end the government shutdown late Monday, bringing Congress one step closer to ending a 41-day impasse.

items.title: Here's what's in the Senate deal to end the government shutdown
items.standfirst: The Senate deal to end the government shutdown would extend funding through January and promise Democrats a vote on health care.
items.content: The Senate deal to end the government shutdown would extend funding through January and promise Democrats a vote on health care.

items.title: US Senate passes funding bill as historic shutdown nears likely end
items.standfirst: It will need to be approved by the House and then signed into law by the president before the government can reopen.
items.content: It will need to be approved by the House and then signed into law by the president before the government can reopen.

items.content: Ahmed al-Sharaa, once branded a terrorist by the US, became the first Syrian leader to visit the White House.

items.title: Trump hosts Syria’s Sharaa at White House, Damascus joins anti-IS group coalition
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump hosted his Syrian counterpart President Ahmed al-Sharaa for unprecedented talks at the White House on Monday. Although the meeting was held behind closed doors and few policy details were provided afterward, Washington welcomed the once-pariah state into its international coalition to fight the Islamic State (IS) group.
items.content: US President Donald Trump hosted his Syrian counterpart President Ahmed al-Sharaa for unprecedented talks at the White House on Monday. Although the meeting was held behind closed doors and few policy details were provided afterward, Washington welcomed the once-pariah state into its international coalition to fight the Islamic State (IS) group.

items.title: Trump threatens to sue BBC for $1 billion over January 6 speech edit
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for $1 billion, alleging that the British public broadcaster attempted to “interfere in the presidential election” last year by editing his January 6th speech. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez has the details, as two top executives have already resigned amid mounting pressure on the organization.

items.content: The head of the BBC and the British broadcaster’s top news executive both resigned after criticism of the way the organization edited a speech by President Donald Trump. The BBC said Director-General Tim Davie and news CEO Deborah Turness had both decided to leave the corporation.

items.title: Israel’s parliament advances ‘terrorists’ death penalty bill
items.standfirst: Israel’s parliament has advanced a controversial bill that would allow the death penalty for ‘terrorists’.
items.content: Israel’s parliament has advanced a controversial bill that would allow the death penalty for ‘terrorists’.

items.title: Israeli bill proposing death penalty for ‘terrorists’ clears first parliamentary vote
items.standfirst: Israel’s parliament on Monday approved a bill in its first reading that would allow the death penalty for “terrorists”, a measure pushed by far-right National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir and aimed largely at Palestinians convicted of killing Israelis. The bill passed 39-16 and requires two more readings.
items.content: Israel’s parliament on Monday approved a bill in its first reading that would allow the death penalty for “terrorists”, a measure pushed by far-right National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir and aimed largely at Palestinians convicted of killing Israelis. The bill passed 39-16 and requires two more readings.

ai_summary: Israel's parliament advanced a bill on the death penalty.
The bill would allow the death penalty for "terrorists".
The bill is aimed at Palestinians who kill Israelis.
The bill passed its first reading in parliament.
Critics say the bill targets only Arabs who kill Jews.
